utterances: I - well, I want to make one quick point.
You know, after the '67 riot, we had the Kerner Commission report which looked at all of the grievances that folks had about why these civil disturbances had.
We took a look at all the grievances that they listed in '68 and looked at Detroit today.
And African-Americans in Detroit, living in the city, for the most part, are in worse shape now than they were in 1967.
I know that disagrees with what Congressman Conyers said earlier on the program, but that's the fact.
That's the data.
I think one thing that's not being talked about is the one thing we're seeing at the city of Detroit is we can track the number of permits pulled and things like that.

And we're actually seeing - now, wait, I'm not saying that things are great - but we're actually seeing a lot of people in all the neighborhoods, when you get a contractor and they pull a permit, people are making improvements to their houses.
They're getting new roofs and new porches and things like that.
So I think that's the signal to us that says maybe things are slightly on the upswing.
You know, I don't like to say comeback city, but I - we are seeing that people are making improvements in their neighborhoods through...
Absolutely.
And only just now have we gotten a new superintendent - don't know what he's going to do yet.
But the schools, absolutely.
You know, Detroit needs kids.
We need families, so.
Rochelle, for people - and you're doing your part, I hope, soon, eventually.
Are you going to...
(LAUGHTER)
...You going to get there?
I mean...
Not at the moment, but...
(CROSSTALK)
If only people could see his face right now.
I know, right?
Rochelle, last 30 seconds.
You and I talked about this several years ago when I told you there wasn't a national chain grocery store in Detroit and you were aghast.
That has changed.
There is a renaissance.
It is real.
We need transportation as well as families.
That's Rochelle Riley.
She's an award-winning columnist at the Detroit Free Press.
In fact, she's the recipient of a new honor - the Ida B.
Wells Award, which she will be awarded at the National Association of Black Journalists Convention this year.

In Britain, biometrics will be used on national identity cards approved by parliament earlier this week, not just a photograph, but an iris scan or fingerprints as well.
Maxine Most of Acuity Marketing Intelligence in Colorado.
As biometrics becomes more and more prevalent, I think what we're going to see is the applications where we would have multiple biometrics.
So you might have facial recognition and a fingerprint.
You might have finger scan and voice recognition, so that you increase the likelihood that this person is who they say they are.
How this technology works, or not, and how it's used by both government and by business?

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
If you've had to produce your birth certificate for identification purposes recently, maybe you noticed how old-fashioned it looks, Well, soon your passport, driver's license, work or school I.D.
might start to look a little antiquated too.
A mere photograph won't be enough.
In Britain this week, for example, parliament approved a plan to require citizens to register their biometric information for use on a national I.D.
card.
That's data like fingerprints, iris scans or vocal patterns, unique biological information.
There are no national I.D.
cards in this country, but digital identification is being used widely in commercial applications.
Students at Gonzaga University use finger scans to pay for meals and other expenses on campus.
Many new computers have biometric fingerprint sensors built in.
We're closer and closer to a world where the eye are not just a window to the soul, but to our bank accounts.
Much of the debate over biometrics centers over civil liberties, issues we've discussed before on this program.
But there are also questions within the industry about accuracy, about cost, privacy, and about the practicality of this kind of identification.
This hour, we'll look at how this technology is advancing and what it means for who you are, and how you'll prove it.
Later in the program, we'll look at Tony Blair's controversial terrorism bill that would outlaw the glorification of terrorism.

card?

card, on the chip that forms part of the I.D.
card.

cards in Britain.

The steakhouse is now leaning on the fine print that limits the discount to 50 percent, but it has still booked all of its reservations for days to come.
